title: Deputy Director Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Misleading and archaic. Will overpromise and then ghost you immediately if they no longer want you. They will also try to pay you the least possible for the most amount of work.
Interview Questions: Average stuff, nothing too special

title: Assistant Director Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States
Interview Descriptions: This was for a position in Atlantic Council's Adrienne Arsht – Rockefeller Foundation Resilience Center, which seems like a small and tight-knit community in the Atlantic Council. I didn't make it past the first interview, but overall, I had a really positive experience. Unlike most interviews I've experienced, the interview felt like a conversation--not an interrogation or an onslaught of behavioral questions. The interviewers seemed genuinely interested in and curious about my interests, motivation, and experience; were engaged throughout; and asked thoughtful questions. It was a joy to talk with them! They also encouraged me to send any other questions I had for them in a follow-up email and were timely with letting me know I hadn't made it to the next round. A+ interview experience, and while I'm disappointed I didn't get the role, I'll definitely keep Arsht-Rock in mind for the future.
Interview Questions: --Introduce yourself and tell us why you are interested in the position. --Tell us about what accomplishment you are most proud of so far in your career. --Tell us about a time you experienced conflict at work and how you resolved it. --What qualities do you look for in a team? --What questions do you have for us? --Also a couple questions about my grad school experience--why I chose the school/degree I did, and what I learned. The interviewer seemed genuinely interested, which felt really nice.

title: Consultant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States
Interview Descriptions: Interview, followed by a written test a few weeks later. Selection process reportedly delayed which can happen but then no news for over 6 months, even after sending a follow-up email. Disappointing to treat candidates this way when they take the time for an interview and to sit a test.
Interview Questions: Why are you the best person for the position?

title: Internship Interview

title: Program Assistant Interview

title: Project Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States (Washington, DC)
Interview Descriptions: Interview process included a phone interview, Skype interview, and an in-person interview at Atlantic Council's D.C. offices. Entire process took 3-4 weeks. Like others have said here, I never heard back from them (and I found out someone was hired), even though they reminded me multiple times that I would receive a definite yes/no decision. They asked in the phone interview portion about how much I expected to earn. Translation: "are you willing to pay for D.C. living expenses on a meager salary thousands of $ less than your skills and background are worth to fit our budget?" I do appreciate how open the interviewers were about the working culture and operations at the Atlantic Council, as I spoke with members of the program (very friendly, but overworked), who gave clear insights into how they manage their daily workload. Think I dodged a major bullet.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to work at Atlantic Council?

title: Program Assistant Interview

Very easy and standard interview questions related to my relevant experience and interest in the organization. Overall, it was a very strange experience as the Program Director was not very professional and generally I received all-around strange vibes.
Interview Questions: What do you know about the Atlantic Council?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States (Washington, DC) in Jul 2015

Interview Questions: How would your colleagues describe you?

title: Program Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States in Jun 2015
Interview Descriptions: About two weeks after submitting my application, I was notified that I had been selected for a first round Skype interview. One week later, I interviewed with the Associate Director for the division to which I had applied as well as an associate from HR. They were very friendly and professional. I really appreciated that they started by having me say what I knew about the Atlantic Council, as I felt it was a clever way of ensuring that applicants had read the website/other materials (I had reviewed everything I could get my hands on, so this questions wasn't difficult for me). The Associate Director reached out a few days later with an invitation to a second round interview as well as a writing/editing assignment, which I found odd but took in stride. The second interview was with the director of the division, also via Skype. Most of the questions in both interviews were fairly straightforward, though in the second round I was asked extremely specific questions about a work experience from a few years prior. I will admit that I had read the Glassdoor company reviews prior to interviewing and as such was on the lookout for indications of the overworking specified in many reviews.
Interview Questions: What is the Atlantic Council, and what does the Atlantic Council do?

title: Program (Research) Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at Atlantic Council of the United States (Washington, DC) in May 2015
Interview Descriptions: After completing a series of interviews with the Atlantic Council, I am still in shock at how unprofessional the process was. Although I thought the first round, during which I was grilled for over an hour by four employees, went relatively well, I was constantly interrupted by the interviewers who at one point stopped to talk among themselves about something completely unrelated to me. The second round included a writing test which I believed I aced, a fact confirmed by the directors. The third round included an interview with the office directors, although using the term "interview" was perhaps a stretch. This experience was by far the worst interview I have ever been exposed to. The directors grilled me with questions that were completely subjective and biased for an hour. They harassed me with minute details about my answers and over-analyzed every tiny gesture and word that I used. I felt as though I was at an interrogation and not an interview. By the end of the interview, I wanted to laugh when the directors informed me about the salary. Absolutely ludicrous and not at all feasible in DC!  Don't waste your time!
Interview Questions: What would you say to a media member when pressed about ___

title: Internship Interview

title: Intern Interview

title: Publications/Graphic Design Coordinator Interview

Interview Descriptions: The interview process was strange - I was simultaneously interviewed by an HR manager and the person who would be my supervisor, but the HR manager was pretty much running the show. They made it very clear that I was to work long hours, but be totally ok with it because I had a passion for the industry. At this point, my potential supervisor said "but usually when I come in on a weekend, it's because i want to!" This seemed like a red flag to me, and apparently the feeling was mutual because I was not asked back for a second interview - I got the feeling that either I seemed too old or that my salary requirements were too high, so I wasn't surprised or dissappointed by this.
Interview Questions: Why are you interested in leaving your current company?

title: Intern Interview
